Name: Jungle!
Description:
Get into the heart of the adventure, clearing a path through the dense vegetation with our machetes, in search of lost trails that lead us to the legendary temple.
Choose one of the 6 explorers, each with his own peculiarities, and challenge the dangers of the wild jungle and the dark conspiratorial plot of the most fearsome secret criminal organization in the world: the G.H.O.S.T.!

Name: Battlefleet Gothic Armada
Description:
The only expansion for Games Workshop's Battlefleet Gothic; Armada both expanded the fleet lists from the base game and introduced fleet lists for many of the factions that were not present in the original game- although some factions received as few as two ships.

Many new technologies were also introduced, such as all-around area of effect weapons (mostly due to the fact that new alien races were now in the game that were not present in the Warhammer universe when Battlefleet Gothic debuted, i.e. the Tau). As with all Games Workshop products, a fair amount of background and flavor text is present in the book, expanding the space battles beyond the scope of just the Gothic War.

New Fleets Introduced In Armada:
Tau Empire navy (Includes Kroot, Demiurg, and Nicassar vessels)
Dark Eldar corsairs
Craftworld Eldar fleet
Tyranid Hive Fleets
Unique Ork Battleships
and Necron Harvest Fleets

Expands:

    Battlefleet Gothic

Name: Par-K
Description: Par-k is a five-in-a-row game played on a 14×14 grid divided into four quadrants.  Each quadrant is further divided into seven "lanes" of seven squares each.  During a turn a player may either: 1) place a new piece anywhere on the board, 2) jump a piece, or 3) slide a piece.  Whenever a piece ends its move orthogonally adjacent to two or more opposing pieces, one of these pieces is bumped along its lane.  The first player to get five pieces in a row wins.

Name: Texasopoly
Description:
Monopoly with University of Texas themed spaces and college-themed tokens.

Tokens include an alarm clock, pencil, gym shoe, bicycle, and graduation cap.

Board spaces include The Drag, Jester Center, The Longhorn Band, Main Mall, Memorial Stadium, Texas Union, and the Main Building.

Cards include:
 Recite the Fight Song or Lose One Turn. 
 Parking in Faculty Parking! Pay $50. 
 Graduation Fee! Pay $25 for each Year of Credit and $100 for each Diploma. 
 Dead Week. Lose 2 turns to study. 
 Advance to Bevo and run him once around the board. Collect $200 each time you pass "Register and Proceed."

Name: Big Builder
Description:
Big Builder appears to be an educational game, as it was produced in part by the Ohio State University Research Foundation and is an "Industrial Art Curriculum Project," according to the box.

In the game players move around a set of different tracks in an effort to bid on and complete major construction projects (e.g., a bridge, a dam, etc.). Each player will end up with a different set of costs and savings and can choose the profit margin that they will use to bid for each project, although they are also limited by their bonding capacity - this is $250K at the start of the game and the object is to end up with the largest.

Name: Cryptyc
Description:
Cryptyc is a somewhat unusual word search game. The board is a hexagonal grid (9 cells on a side), with each cell containing a number from 1 to 20. At the start of the game, English consonants are assigned to the numbers (written in an auxiliary area, not in the grid). After that, each player looks for words that can be made from chains of adjacent cells snaking in any combination of directions, ignoring vowels and allowing a single letter to stand for a double letter.

Each player writes down their word on paper and then, on their turn, writes the appropriate consonants on the cells used and challenges their opponents to guess the word. A successful guess gives the points to the opponent, otherwise the player gets a point per cell used. In either case the used cells are out of play.

There are a few further wrinkles, including one where, if a player manages to enclose an area with his or her color and the edge of the board, he or she may claim all the enclosed spaces.

Name: Globe-Trotters
Description: Object of the game is be the first player to visit three sites on each continent selected for the game, then return home free of debt. Players roll to determine the mode of travel they must use for their turn, then use a range finder to tell how much it will cost to travel to a destination served by that mode of travel. Players must travel if possible (unless they are on a Point of Entry space trying for a reward), and may go into debt while traveling. Reward spaces are scattered on the board to help players gain back money, and thus get out of debt.

Name: Creeps!
Description:
Manufacturers Blurb: Creeps! The game that strikes terror at the heart! Pick up a dagger and strike the vampire in his coffin... but tread carefully or he'll awake with a flash and a screech!
A spine chilling game for children over 7 years and adults too!

A game of chance and skill - pit your wits against the Vampire. Get him before he gets you!

Game Summary: Players race to move one of their daggers to the centre of the board and slay the vampire. Each player begins the game with 5 daggers, and places one of them on the starting 'foot-print' at the beginning of the game. Each turn every player gets 6 movement points to share between his daggers (ie move 1 dagger forward 6 footprints, or 2 daggers 3 footprints each, or any combination up to a total of 6). You can 'leapfrog' your own daggers, (but may never have 2 daggers on the same footprint) and at the end of each move the dagger is 'stabbed' into the board. When a dagger is placed in one of the randomly selected footprints the Vampire will let out a bloodcurdling scream causing that dagger to be removed from the game. Players have to remember which footprints will wake the Vampire and avoid them for the rest of the game. The first player to reach the centre of the board and stab his dagger into the heart of the Vampire wins!

Name: Ratzolino
Description:
This game for Ages 3 and up and premiered at Essen 2000.

Included are 19 various wooden play figures, mainly animals, and 10 game markers.

In the first game the pieces are laid out in plain sight of all.  An older player reads a story and when any of the figures is named, each player tries to be the first to grab it. If the figure has already been named, the player takes a marker instead.  At the end of the story the player with the most pieces wins.

In the second game, the pieces are laid out in an order and the player must identify them to get a point.

The last game is one of remembering which pieces have been named.

It is similar to the earlier Ratz-Fatz and some of the scenarios can be used to make a larger combined game, so in some ways this is an expansion kit.

Integrates with:

    Ratz-Fatz

Name: Forces of Valor: Battle Tactics Game
Description:
Designed as a free download to promote their line of replica military figures and vehicles(mainly the 1:72 scale lines), the Forces of Valor Battle Tactics game offers surprising realism and tactical possibilities for something designed as a promotional tool.

From their website, players can download the corresponding stat cards for the figures they own; the stat cards have attributes found on most wargame stat cards- movement, weapon abilities and strength, etc.

Firing is handled with dice rolling- basically, the longer the range, the less accurate the gun. Combat has many options available giving players the option to make mobility kills and flanking shots among other things.

The game is really more or less designed for small skirmish style ground combat although air to air and air to ground rules are covered very briefly.

Name: Bowlem
Description:
Bowlem The parlor bowling game. The scoring for this game is exactly the same as regular bowling. (Although given the rules, the game is actually more like CANDLEPIN Bowling, a form of bowling prevalent in the North East portion of the country - especially in Massachusetts and New Hampshire and Maine - In Candlepin Bowling the ball is much smaller (ball has no holes and fits in the palm of your hand) and you get 3 tries to knock all the pins down. The pins that are knocked down but remain on the deck stay there during the remainder of the frame. (Those pins are called deadwood and can be used to deflect the ball to help knock down the remaining pins to help you make spares.)

There are ten dice representing the pins, each having a spot on some sides of the dice.  Each player has three shakes. Rolling 10 spots with one roll is a strike. You put aside dice that have spots on them and then re-roll the rest. if you get spots on the rest of the dice you make a spare. You then have a third roll if you make all ten spots with the third roll you score a 10.

Name: Numba Duel
Description:
A game for two players:

Object of the game is to arrange unbroken diagonal rows of 3 or more tokens of one color and, by doing so, to score the highest number of points at game's end.

Alternatively, each player have to roll dice and place a token of his colors on the board, selecting a free spot near one of the number rolled. If its not possible, the turn is lost for the current player.

After a player went out of token, the game end. The winner is the player with the most points according to the number and length of the diagonal rows of his color on the board.

The scoring is:

3 - 1 point
4 - 3 points
5 - 6 points
6 - 10 points
7 - 15 points
8 - 21 points
9 - 28 points

The game include:
- 2 dice
- 58 colored tokens (29 for each player)
- a game board (58 holes braketed by two numbers from 1 to 6))
- Rules sheet

Name: Elements
Description:
Like Rock-Paper-Scissors, Elements is a fun, fast-paced game of circular dominance. Prepare for action as earth, wind, water and fire collide in a battle of strength and dominance to see which one will prevail. Elements features several different games from quick and easy to delightfully strategic.

The object of Elements is to capture cards. As in nature, each element dominates another and can capture any card in the element regardless of strength, but cards in the same element must rely on the strength of their force.

Name: Dilbert C.E.O.
Description:
The game board represents a company once ruled by an evil C.E.O.  He is now dead and his job has yet to be filled.  Those who reach the top will receive great power and wealth.

You are one of the employees who seek this position.  You will meet difficult tasks, make friends and collect stuff on your way.  It does not matter how good you get at your job, as it will all be in vain if you are not the first to replace the C.E.O.

This game is a clone of the Games Workshop game Talisman, set in the Dilbert universe.

The designer thanks Bob Harris for creating Talisman for all of us to enjoy.

The designer thanks Scott Adams for creating the Dilbert universe we all love to read.

Name: Jumbo Zoo
Description: Collect peanuts for your hungry baby elephant by taking part in exciting challenges. Guess in which hand your opponent is hiding the peanuts, be the first player to find the right combination of animal and color, or be the first to trumpet "Toot!" when a peanut appears on the die. But also watch out for the zoo keeper who wants to steal your precious peanuts! Who will be the first to collect a complete meal of 15 peanuts for their baby elephant?

Name: Hornet Leader II: Marine Air
Description:
Hornet Leader II is based on the original award-winning design published by GMT Games back in 1991.

Like the original game, Hornet Leader II - Marine Air is designed from the ground up as a solitaire game.

The game places you in command of the pilots and aircraft of a modern day squadron of Marine AV-8 Harrier fighters.

It features AV-8s, more pilots, and campaigns.

When you play the game, you will plan and carry-out missions in various campaign settings.  Each campaign takes place in a different era, so your weapon options change with each campaign.

A major part of the game is mission planning. You get to decide how your Hornets are to be armed, and which pilots are best for the mission based on their Air-to-Air and Air-to-Ground skills.

Missions are quickly resolved with the priority placed on speed and realism. Hornet Leader II has retained all the key decision-making aspects of the original game, while greatly streamlining the game mechanics.

While performing each mission, you get to decide how your pilots engage the enemy Bandits, SAMs, and AAA Sites. This makes for some tough choices, the more suppression munitions, you haul to the target, the safer your pilots will be, but the less likely you are to destroy the target.

Available in two formats:

- Virtual Tabletop Game using the Vassal Engine
- PDF files to download and print.

Not a complete game, you must own Hornet Leader II.

Name: World Series
Description:
World Series by the Lowe Company was produced in 1940.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Taffy's Baubles and Bangles Game
Description: Taffy's Baubles and Bangels Game by Transogram is a game for girls. The object of the game is to collect the best jewelry during the game.

Name: Parlor Baseball Game
Description: The Parlor Baseball Game was produced by the Parlor Baseball game Company in 1903.  Players roll a die with hits (HR for home run, for example) to score runs and strike outs on a square board.

Name: Swat Baseball
Description:
Swat Baseball by Milton Bradley was produced in 1948.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Managers Baseball Game
Description:
Managers' Baseball Game by Burton was produced in 1949.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Renegade Legion: Distant Fire
Description:
From the back cover:
Fall: 6818
A TOG task force suddenly emerged from T-space around Gustaviv's Regret.
Their mission: seize Gustaviv's Regret for the Empire & crush any opposition.  The invasion, code-named Distant Fire, signaled the beginning of one of TOG's longest and bloodiest campaigns.
Distant Fire, a Renegade Legion scenario pack for use with all four Renegade Legion game systems, cover the key battles of the invasion of Gustaviv's Regret.

Subtitled "The Battle for Gustaviv's Regret," this is a scenario book for Renegade Legion: Centurion, Interceptor, Leviathan, and Legionnaire. It includes 16 scenarios (*) and rules for campaigns. 72 pages with a GREAT David Martin cover. FASA SKU 5403.

(*) Only the first scenario "Deaf and Blind" use the Legionnaire role playing game rules.

Name: Siebenpunkt
Description:
This game which premiered at Essen 2000 is for Ages 5 and up.  It is educational in nature -- children who have some ability to count are able to develop their skill.  Each of the games is a bit more challenging than the last so once they master one game they "graduate" on to the next.

Initially the child simply counts. Later the child uses an included ink stamp to make a number of marks equal to a die roll.  Later, players have different colored pencils and take turns coloring parts of the picture.  They must figure out the number that they can color.  The player coloring the most wins.  So children are learning counting while they think they're only playing a game.

Name: Action Ice Hockey Game
Description: Action Ice Hockey by Pressman is a very simple dexterity game where each player has a stick and tries to score goals on a playing board that looks like a platter, shaped like an oval arena, with a circular wooden disk acting as a goaltender in front of a hole in the boards that is the goal.

Name: Carl Yastrzemski Action Baseball
Description:
Carl Yastrzemski Action Baseball from Pressman is the official Yastrzemski Baseball game and features and all metal field, automatic umpire and a scoreboard.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by the Yahoo Baseball Games Group. A more complete description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Letra-Mix: Spiel mit Sätzen
Description:
This game complements the Letra-Mix game in Schmidt Spiele's range, which is a dice game with individual letters on the faces of the dice.

Spiel mit Sätzen translates as 'game with sentences' and the dice in this game have words on them, rather than just letters. The game comes with 24 word dice, a timer and a dice cup. The rules say the game can be played in a group or in partnerships, but it does recommend that when more than six play, they do so in partnerships.

Each player (or partnership) casts the dice and attempts to form complete sentences before the timer runs out. Words can be placed crossword-style, which means that a word could be used in a horizontal as well as vertical direction. The score is 1 point for every word that forms part of a sentence (words used in both vertical and horizontal sentences score 2 points). However, 1 point is deducted for each die that is not used.

Name: Flames of War: Bloody Omaha – The Battle for Omaha Beach D-Day, 6 June 1944
Description:
Bloody Omaha is a source book for Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game covering the fighting on Omaha Beach.  Included are army lists for the forces involved, including the US Rangers and 1st and 29th Infantry Divisions, and the German 352nd Infantry Division.

Also included are scenarios, modeling tips and historical background.

Name: Pat Morans Own Ball Game
Description:
Pat Morans Own Ball Game Baseball game from 1919 by Smith Kline French Co.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Bob Feller's Big League Baseball Game
Description:
Bob Feller's Big League Baseball Game by Saalfield Publishing Co.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Electric Baseball
Description:
An application for a U.S. patent was filed in December 1927 by James M. Prentice of Holyoke, Massachusetts. Prentice was 17 years old. The patent, for "Electric Baseball," was granted less than a year later, and Jim Prentice Electric Baseball, under a variety of titles and in a variety of forms, would go on to a production run of more than thirty years.

Prentice initially sold, or at least licensed, the rights to his invention to Parker Brothers, the game-publishing giant of nearby Salem -- probably to help fund his college tuition at the University of New Hampshire, whence he graduated with a degree in mathematics. Parkers produced Electric Base Ball Game, arguably the first electrical boardgame ever, in the very early 1930s.

Despite the enduring popularity of the fondly-remembered Prentice games, their more than two dozen variations and their chronology are poorly documented, and Prentice himself (1910-2005) seems a mysterious figure to most.

Prentice regained control of his patent by the mid-1930s and set himself up in business as Electric Game Co..  One of the first products of The Electric Game Company -- perhaps the very first, and among the simplest of all Prentice baseball games -- was Electric Base Ball "version D02," featuring the "Electric Bat."  Prentice evidently got rights to Parker Brothers' graphics as well.  He told the Union-News that in his first year of production, he sold about a hundred games at five dollars each.

Very similar to both the D02 and the Parker Brothers game, another of the earliest varieties of Electric Base Ball was the "version DD24," also featuring the "Electric Bat." The "D" and "DD" clearly denoted editions using a single D battery and two D batteries -- perhaps the last obvious indicia in a long list of cryptic Prentice codes. The games were personally assembled by Prentice and a few assistants.

Another early-looking version of Prentice electric baseball is Wonder Baseball Game. The illustrated batter would be reused in later variations of the box lid.

Not only is Wonder again similar to the early models above, the promo literature included in the box trumpets both the Wonder game and Electric Base Ball Model D02, as well as Electric Football, and identifies all as available in 1938. Oddly, the Wonder gameboard indicates "patent pending," despite the 1928 patent used on much later models.

Wonder Baseball had an edition packaged in a slip-cover sort of box and apparently devoid of battery compartments, control buttons, and lights. It seems to be a non-electric model, perhaps a wartime revision.

Prentice saved a little money by providing box lids but no box bottoms for his games, leaving many vendors of second-hand games today to think that one part's missing. It's not. Adding to some latter-day confusion, Electric Game Co. box lids and gameboards do not always match up.  Prentice was not one to waste a nickel, so it's very likely that, even while new gameboard models were being designed, produced, and sold, old box-lid inventory was being used until it was exhausted, and only at that point would new and redesigned box lids be printed.

The lid most often associated with the earliest 1930s versions of Electric Base Ball is a red box with the batter illustration above the title.  Two words on the gameboard, "Baseball" is one word on the box.  The source of the illustration -- the same batter seen on Wonder Baseball Game -- remains unknown.

Slightly later editions of the lid added the phrase "Big League" above "Electric Baseball" -- all in a new font -- and are in fact usually seen covering 
Big League Electric Baseball Model B-4, which was produced from about 1938 through 1941.  Prentice's All-American Electric Football and Collegiate Electric Basketball also debuted by 1938.

Like the earliest versions, the B-4 measures about 16x14" -- the standard dimensions of all Prentice Electric Baseball games until the Super De Luxe editions of the early 1950s.

A fourth edition of the red box replaces "Big League" with "Jim Prentice."  Jim Prentice Electric Baseball, probably from about 1940, sports a version of the cover illustration on the gameboard itself.

The legend added to the fifth red box variation reads "This Game Operates Electrically Or Mechanically."  Jim Prentice Electric Baseball Dual Control Model, is a little lighter on the bulbs and wiring and the need for batteries, hinting that this too is not just post-1940 but a wartime product.

A slightly simpler version of Jim Prentice Electric Baseball Dual Control Model (had two knobs, no illustration). The two Dual Control models are the only versions of Electric Baseball so far found carrying a different patent number -- confirming not only their 1942 invention, but also that they were not a Prentice design.  George P Alderman and Herbert H Fredrick had been the people granted the patent on that gameboard.

The patent was later licensed to a company called Mastercraft, which produced the game as Prolectric Baseball in 1951.  Mastercraft also turned out Prolectric Football and possibly other games in the '50s.

The famous "alligator-finish" white box is assumed by many to be early 1930s vintage, but this box lid is almost always seen with Models E120, 68-B, 48-B, and 63-B, all verifiably from the late 1940s. Model E120 dates to 1947. The cartoon of the swinging batter is based on an early-'30s painting by noted illustrator J. F. Kernan.

(Source)

Name: Base Ball
Description:
Base Ball by the J.H. Singer company produced in 1886

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by the Yahoo Baseball Games Group; antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims.

* * see Community Wiki comments below

Name: Home Diamond Baseball
Description:
Home Diamond Baseball by the Home Diamond Company 1915

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by: Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims at the following site http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

A description of the game will be created from information received by members of the group.

Name: AE-WWII
Description:
Taken from the Darkson Designs website:

"It is 1946. The greatest conflict mankind has ever known has entered its seventh bloody year. Tens of millions have already fallen, yet the war rages on. No corner of the globe has been spared, the shadow of battle hovers above every land. Millions have been left homeless, driven from the charred carcasses of once great cities. Millions more cower beneath the iron heel of foreign rule. Awesome weapons of destruction rain down upon the earth, blasting the land itself into a blackened cinder. Mankind stands on the edge of midnight as the wheel of history turns toward its darkest hour."

AE-WWII is a alternate-history WWII game played with metal miniatures- the miniature range is currently very new, but several new releases are planned for 2007.

Name: PatimPatamPatum
Description:
PatimPatamPatum is a special majorities game whose scenario is the popular and traditional festival of "La Patum" in the Catalan city of Berga, near the Pyrenees, recently declared "Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity" by the UNESCO. The game does not intend to faithfully reproduce the festival, but just be a funny competition among the players grasping some of the feeling of the festival.

Each player represents a group of patumaires (i.e. those participating in the festival) and he or she should lead his or her patumaires through the old city streets, trying to reach the special squares where the festival is held. The final aim of the players is to gather the maximum number of patumaires in these squares at the end of each round. But there is a problem: the squares are pretty small and there is no room for everybody. If the squares are full you'll have to manage as best as you can in order to throw out some competitor, while trying to keep there your own patumaires. To help you in this task you should use wisely the various cards and popular characters of the festival: some ones will help you in reaching the squares, some others will help you in defending yourself from the other players' pushes.

The game has three rounds and each player can use his cards to move the patumaires as well as the character cards, which allows some special (and sort of magical) action. At the end of each round the players obtain points by their mere presence in the squares and, in some cases, even more points by having a majority there. You'll have to maintain always an equilibrium in your cards: will you spend your cards mainly for trying to reach all the places or better keep the highest card for defending against your competitor's pushes? Will you spend that 6-valued card for his movement value or for his character's special action?


    Released October 2007.



    Winner of the 6th Game Creation Contest Award at the Fira JocJoc in Tona, Catalonia, Spain (November 2007).

Name: Eye Spy
Description:
(Translated from the box, in Norwegian)

Does your memory last for more than 30 seconds?

"Eye Spy" is an exiting and challenging board game about observation, memory and luck. It is played with 2 teams, and the team that sees best and remember the most will win.

Memorize a picture for 30 seconds and answer questions read by the other team. Try to find matching tiles on the board, or guess which balls are under which cup after they have been moved around. For each successfully solved challenge your team scores a point. The aim is to be the first team to collect 10 points and then pass a final challenge to win.

Entertaining and fun for all ages!

Name: Smart aS
Description:
Smart aS is an educational aid with a unique equalizing system that allows a struggling student to compete competitively against a gifted student or adult.

Smart aS targets everything from colours, shapes to phonics, reading, writing, spelling and maths right up to sixth grade and beyond with additional extension curricula.

Play is as simple as: throw dice, complete maths equation and move counter that amount, draw card and answer question corresponding to square colour.

Everyone starts in the Green section the easiest game. This allows the players to understand how to play. Then each player slowly progresses as he/she masters the ability and skill to the Yellow Section, then the Blue Section and the Red Sections of the Rules & Instruction book.

Apart from the first few games where everyone is in the Green Section, additional games can have every student /player on the different Colour Coded Levels of the Rules & Instruction, playing together at the same time. This allows a child or less able student to play competitively against an able student or adult.

Name: Tomb of Gold
Description: 2-4 Players (archaeologists) climb 5 levels of this stunning Mayan temple to get Gold. Competitors try to steal the gold, and bring it back to their Base camp to win! Hidden dangers lie under spinning layers.  For ages 10 to adult.

Name: Vacation Spin
Description:
This game allows the players to experience their dream vacations in exotic destinations.  You can go scuba diving in Tahiti or climb the Great Wall of China for example.  It involves learning interesting trivia.

Ages 12 and up There is a patented spin mechanism which shows varying prices as in real travel.

Name: Swordplay:  Rising Sun
Description:
Battle For The Honor And Glory Of Your House!

Swordplay: Rising Sun is a fast paced non-collectible card game of martial arts combat.  Face your opponents in hand to hand combat using a wide variety of kicks, punches and more exotic maneuvers.  Wield a variety of classic martial arts weapons including Sai, Throwing Stars and more.  Build your Chi to unleash devastating attacks on your opponents bringing honor to your house.

Includes: 60 full-color cards (2 Heroes and a 58 card Combat Deck), dice, damage markers and rules for two player duels, multi-player battles and combining this game with other swordplay games for cross-era battles.

Name: Cha-Cha Belgaquiz
Description:
Cha-cha is the trademark of a Belgian chocolate wafer. 
You could collect three different card boxes (black, yellow, red : the colours of the Belgian flag). Included were 55 cards with questions in two languages (Dutch and French, languages spoken in Belgium). All trivia questions concerning Belgium.

+  Who was the fourth king of Belgium?

+ Which chocolate based candy contains different ingredients?

+  Who was the first Belgian to walk on the moon?

+ Which famous statue has more than 600 different costumes?

If you collected the bar codes of the candy, you could get a board, dices and jettons (counters) to complete the game.

Name: Dragon Tower
Description:
A prince and a princess are locked up in a tower, guarded by a Dragon. The players try to free them. 
The box of the game is the board on which you build a tower. And on the tower sits a Dragon. 
To throw the dice, you throw it in the tower and it rolls out underneath. 
Players move along the board, trying to collect good apples (there are also bad apples). Finally the ascend the tower, but must be careful not to fall down. 
First on top of the tower, wins the game.

Name: Back Talk
Description: You move along a board and you draw cards. On the cards are words you've got the draw on the back of a team member. He has to guess the word.

Name: Form A Word
Description: A Scrabble-type crossword game, but the goal is to get rid of your tiles (they don't have a point value). At the beginning of her turn, the players spins a spinner, and it decides if she has to put her tiles at the end of a word, at the beginning of a word, between two words (thus creating a third, new word), or anywhere. If she cannot do it, she has to draw some new tiles, depending which tasks she failed. The winner gets points equal to the remaining tiles of other players. altogether three rounds are played.

Name: Unearth
Description:
WINNER 2006 KublaCon Game Design Contest

Bring your maps, shovels, and sense of adventure as you and rival archaeologists travel to remote ruins in search of the greatest artifacts. Beware, for this journey can be a dangerous one as your rivals seek to sabotage you at every turn, and these ancient sites contain giant pits, huge boulders, and even death traps! Do you have the courage to overcome all the obstacles and collect the most valuable treasures, or will you be one crowbar short of your goal?

2-5 Players 
Ages 8 and up 
60 Minutes

Objective: Each player attempts to collect as many Treasure cards as he can. Each Treasure card has a point value listed on it (1-5 points.) The player with the highest point total wins.

Name: Bobby Shantz's Baseball Game
Description:
Bobby Shantz's Baseball Game by Realistic Games Mfg. Company was produced in 1954.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group

Name: Bobby Shantz Magic Catcher Game
Description: Bobby Shantz Magic Catcher Game was published by Regent Games Inc in 1953.

Name: Carl Hubbell "Mechanical" Baseball Game
Description:
Carl Hubbell "Mechanical" Baseball Game was published by the Gotham Pressed Steel Corp. in 1947.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by the Yahoo Baseball Games Group. A more complete description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Christy Mathewson's Base Ball Game
Description:
Christy Mathewson's Base Ball Game by the Mathewson Game Co. was published in 1918.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group

Name: Roger Maris Baseball Game
Description:
The Roger Maris Baseball Game published by Play-Rite Inc. in 1962. This Roger Maris Game has to be one of the best post-war baseball board games in the hobby. This game is different than the Maris game made by Pressman during the same year. This game was issued by Play-Rite Games of Jeffersonville IN. The box cover has two awesome pictures of Maris in his Yankees uniform. The board pictures him twice, too. the best part of the game though, are the cards. Each card has a picture of Maris & his facsimile autograph.   The game includes a fabulous board, a cardboard score board, a ball & strike indicator  and 88 cards to control the action. A better description  will come from:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

Name: Planetreisen
Description:
(Translated from their homepage, from Norwegian)

Here you have a game which is both fun, exiting and educational. The game does not demand any prior knowledge. The players travel around in our solar system and meet surprises and possibilities. The player who is the first to have visited all the planets is the game's winner.

Name: Fusilier
Description:
Fusilier: Tactical Combat in the Age of Napoleon is a 53-page miniatures rule set for 15mm figures.  Popular in Wisconsin and play tested for years at the University of Wisconsin game club.  Jim Harkonen's rules focus on the differences in formation in terms of fire, movement, damage taken, and morale, far more than most such rules.  The rules also focus on relative position and its effects on morale.  While relatively simple, any player who isn't thinking a few turns ahead in terms of position and formation is sure to be another casualty of war.  All rules are summarized on just three movement, fire, and morale charts.

Order of Play:
1. Movement
     Reaction die roll
     Charges and checks
     Pursuit and out of control checks
     Movement declaration
     Movement Execution
2. Fire
3. Movement and Fire morale checks
4. Flinches, routs, and pursuits
5. Melee
6. Melee morale checks
7. Flinches, routs, and pursuits
8. Messages and Rally

Name: Warmaster Annual 2002
Description:
Released in 2002, this expansion of Warmaster includes 19 pages of updates to the basic rules along with rules for Lizardman, Bretonnian, Kislev, and Vampire Armies.  Also included are the four best articles from the previous year's Warmaster magazine.

Expands:

     Warmaster

Name: Top It
Description:
From the box:

"Everybody's shooting for the high scoring spot - 
Knock off your opponents and come out on top!"

Box measures approximately 14" x 19" x 2 1/4".

Marbles are flicked into shallow, point scoring depressions on a gently inclining plastic board. The top half of the playing surface is triangular, so as scoring depressions increase in value they also decrease in number.

Highest total score wins.

Name: MicroWorld
Description:
Embark on a journey as you develop new settlements and race to become the largest town. If you enjoy exploration and resource trading games, you'll love MicroWorld. As you move around the beautifully illustrated game board, you build cabins, churches, blacksmiths, trading posts, mills, fortresses, storehouses, and more. The larger your cities become, the more you are able to accomplish because each building gives your city a special benefit. Whether you enjoy building an empire passively through farming and logging, or furiously through war and pillaging others, this game lets up to six players be who they want to be and that's what makes it such a great game!

(The above description is based on text from the publisher's website:  http://www.biglittlegames.com/microworld.php)

    website no longer active

Name: Panzer Grenadier: Iron Curtain
Description:
In the years immediately following the defeat of Nazi Germany, some leaders among the victorious Allies believed that war between the two remaining superpowers was not only inevitable, it would come very soon. The United States and the Soviet Union continued to design and build new armored vehicles and other weapons for this looming war, but the “Cold War” would drag on for almost 45 years without ever resulting in open battle.

Iron Curtain is a supplement introducing the post-war weapons of the two superpowers to the Panzer Grenadier system. The scenarios are all hypothetical, of course, but are based on what generals of either side believed would be the course of a war in the years immediately after 1945. This module is not playable by itself, but requires ownership of Road to Berlin and Battle of the Bulge.

For those fascinated by huge tanks with big guns, this is the ultimate in tactical armored wargaming. New pieces include the Soviet Josef Stalin III and Josef Stalin IV heavy tanks, T-44 medium tank and Su101 assault gun. There are also infantry armed with the awesome AK-47 assault rifle, still a front-line weapon around the world 60 years after its development.

An American player will need powerful weapons to counter that arsenal, and Iron Curtain provides. There are M26 “Pershing” heavy tanks, Sherman “Jumbo” assault tanks, M24 Chaffee light tanks, M4 Sherman tanks with a 76mm gun, M28 ultra-heavy assault tanks, and M29, M30 and M32 heavy tanks. Plus M36 tank destroyers, M39 full-tracked armored personnel carriers, and 90mm anti-tank guns.

This game is part of the Panzer Grenadier series

Name: Agrarisch aan- & verkoopspel
Description:
The Agrarisch aan- & verkoopspel (Agrarian sell and buy-game) is a roll and move game produced by the Dutch agrarian cooperation Cebeco and "De Boerenbond" a Dutch agrarian retail cooperation.

Players expand their farm with livestock, greenhouses and tractors on the middle part on the game-board. On the outer track of the gameboard players move their pawn in a roll and move style, landing on some spaces gives the player the chance to buy above additions to their farms. Other spaces on the outer track can make the player sell produce, enter a cooperation, damage others property, change the market price, pay upkeep or draw a chance card.

Name: Apples to Apples: Yiddish Edition
Description:
This game is completely in Yiddish--cards, box, and instructions.  It is "based on the Apples to Apples 9+ card set" but cards have been changed to reflect the Yiddish culture.  Recommended Ages 7 and up

288 cards total.  Language-dependent.

Part of the Apples to Apples Series.

Name: Skattejagten
Description:
Skattejagten (or in English”The treasure hunt”) is a children’s game.
 This game is an treasure hunt adventure with Bamse, Kylling, Kaj and Andrea. 
(Bamse and Kylling are famous from children TV in Denmark.) 
 You can choose to play for either Bamse, Kylling, Kaj or Andrea.  You are on an island full of dangerous animals and great obstacles.

Each time it’s you turn, you can move – either with walking, sailing or flying.

The player who first finds the treasure and returns to his home - will win the game.

Name: Danske Rails
Description:
A web-published variant of the well-known Empire Builder system by Mayfair Games. This game takes place on a much smaller map than the traditional games in the series and is therefore limited to only 2-3 players.

The game can be downloaded here:
http://www.zahag.de/MMsKSg/rails/dr/main.html

Name: Benelux Rails
Description: A web-published variant of the well-known Empire Builder system by Mayfair Games. This game takes place on a much smaller map than the traditional games in the series and is therefore limited to only 2-3 players.

Name: Solitaire Tiles
Description:
Solitaire Tiles is a variant of the classic solitaire game Klondike.  It can be played solo using standard Klondike rules or can be played using a point system.  Each tile has a different point value so choosing the right tile to play can affect your score.

In the two player game, players take turns placing tiles.  Points are score for playing your own tiles but not your opponents.  As different tiles have different point values, it may sometimes be beneficial to play an opponents tile to block him from getting the points.

The game uses a standard "deck" of 52 tiles plus an 4 special tiles (wild & swirls).

Name: Dondi Prairie Race Game
Description: A simple roll and move game based on a cartoon character of the times. The box claims that this is Dondi's Favorite Wild West Game.

Name: Strike Out
Description:
Strike Out by Moen published in 1949.  Description on the box cover: The worlds champion action game for children and adults. Great fun for one and a riot for two or more.  Simple enough for youngsters. Exciting skill game for adults. All the fun and thrills of America's National Pastime.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

A description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Monopoly: Centenarium Benfica 1904-2004
Description:
Special Monopoly edition dedicated to the one hundredth anniversary of the Sport Lisboa e Benfica football club.

This edition was not sold commercially and was distributed solely through the Record sports newspaper.

Name: Union Pacific-opoly
Description:
from the publisher's website:

A game for train lovers across America!

More than 140 years ago, President Abraham Lincoln signed the Pacific Railroad Act.  With this historic stroke of a pen, the stage was set for Union Pacific to open the American West to settlers and, in the process, connect a continent.  The transcontinental route heralded the Industrial Revolution and modernized transportation, turning the grueling, six-month, $1,000 journey from New York to San Francisco into a week long trip costing a mere $70.

It took an army of 20,000 men, working 12 to 16 hours a day, seven days a week, for six years, to connect America east to west by rail.  It was a remarkable feat, as the system was built primarily by hand.  With the driving of the Golden Spike on May 10, 1869, the route was complete, and a vast, largely unpopulated region was poised for growth.

Today, the 50,000 men and women of Union Pacific still connect America’s communities, transporting the raw materials and finished goods that keep our economy, and our country, moving.

Tokens include: Railroad crossing signal; Engineer’s cap, Golden Spike, Caboose, Locomotive, and a Lantern.

Name: Ice Cream-opoly
Description:
from the publisher's website:

It’s our nation’s favorite dessert! We all scream for ice cream! In fact, the average American eats 22 quarts of ice cream per year. We’re the ice cream capital of the world, producing over 1.5 billion gallons of ice cream each year. Seems like most of us just find the stuff to be irresistible!

Ice Cream-opoly is a game celebrating our love of this frozen delight. Players buy favorite ice cream flavors then increase property values by collecting Ice Cream Parlors and trading them in for Ice Cream Factories. It sounds easy enough but pay your double dip fee, get busted in a late night freezer raid, or have the really bad luck of developing Brain Freeze and it becomes a little more difficult, and a lot more fun!

So advance to Scoop! Who knows! You may soon be elected president of the Ice Cream Dream Team…or you may be buying Sugar-Free Toe-Phooey. Gather family and friends. This is one delicious game. And whatever happens, remember - not much goes wrong that a little ice cream won’t fix!

6 custom tokens: Ice Cream Cone, Spoon, Big Smile, Dairy Cow, Scoop, Sundae

Name: Grillin-opoly
Description:
from the publisher's website:

Fire up!

Half a million years ago, either by design or by accident, humans began to cook meat over fire – and we’ve been grilling ever since! In fact, grilling has become one of our most universally enjoyed human experiences. We grill year round, from the East Coast to the West Coast, shoveling snow, swatting flies, huddled under umbrellas, whatever heroics required to keep the fires stoked.

Grillin’-opoly is a game celebrating this fiery phenomenon. Players buy favorite grillin’ properties, then increase their property value by collecting Briquets, and trading them in for Propane Tanks. It sounds easy enough, but lose your License to Grill, have to kiss the cook, or get sent to Burnt to a Crisp, and it becomes a little more difficult…and a lot more fun!

So advance to Fire Up! Who knows! You may soon be designated “Natural Born Griller,” – or you may be diggin’ your burned dog out of the pit! Whatever happens, Grillin’-opoly is a rare treat for all who appreciate THE THRILL OF THE GRILL!

6 custom tokens: Salt Shaker, Corn on the Cob, Hot Dog, Cheeseburger, T-Bone Steak, Pepper

Name: Face to Face
Description:
FACE TO FACE
The Famous Face Guessing Game
Le Jeu Des Portraits-Énigmes
(Description from the back of the box and instruction book)

Tired of playing games with the same old friends... instead, why not invite 560 of the most famous faces in the world into your living room?  Famous faces of your favourite Celebrities, Athletes, Politicians, People in the News and more!
Players get to open windows on one of the four View Finders and guess the names of these famous faces as they are revealed bit by bit.  The face may be on the top of your head but the name might stay on the tip of your tongue.

OBJECT OF THE GAME
To be the first player to collect eight Face cards (two each of colour; Mauve, Peach, Green and Yellow), and also correctly identify a Final Face card.

PLAYERS
Two or more individuals or teams.

EQUIPMENT
One card box; 560 Face cards (140 of each colour; Mauve, Peach, Green, and Yellow); one die; four View Finders (one of each colour; Mauve, Peach, Green, and Yellow) with locking windows; six playing pieces; and a game board.

Name: Le Mystere des Masques
Description:
The year is 1791 and France continues its headlong slide into a state of anarchy and terror. As the starving French people riot openly in the blood-stained streets,  leaders of the country's various rival factions continue to quarrel and fight in their attempts to seize outright control.

Meanwhile, following their desperate failed attempt to flee the country, the deeply unpopular King Louis 16th and his equally despised wife, Marie Antoinette, have been taken to the Bastille fortress, where they are now being held under guard, "for their own safety".

In a brave attempt to inject a small degree of normality back into the royal couple's lives, Cardinal Richelieu decides to continue as planned, with the  Masked Ball he was intending to hold in honor of the King’s 40th birthday - albeit on a much smaller scale, with just the jail’s four current residents, and each of their guests, in attendance.

However, with just an hour to go until the party begins, Richelieu is horrified to discover King's lifeless body lying slumped across his dressing room table, having been poisoned with some form of deadly toxin!
Confusion soon replaces shock, however, when a second ‘living and breathing’ Louis then appears, identical to the first, and claims that he is the real king, and that the corpse is obviously just a ridiculous impostor!

With the future of France at stake, Richelieu realizes he must enlist the help of all those attending the ball, if he is to catch his killer and unravel this mystery, before news of the terrible events escapes, and a panic takes hold of the city!

Name: Yankee Doodle
Description: Produced by the Crandall & Ellis Company in 1940, the object of the game is to fill in missing words from famous quotes, most of which originate in American history. It comes with 80 quote cards, 28 red, 28 white and 28 blue counters, 400 alphabet letter tiles and a Yankee Doodle Answer Book.  Examples of some of the quotes used in the game include "Remember the Maine" (Richard Hovey), "Give me liberty or give me death" (Patrick Henry), "We are through with politicians. Give us Men!" (Arthur Guiterman).

Name: Orbit, a Brain Game
Description: A simple trivia game.  Large cards with questions on one side and drawings on the other.  Each drawing is different and is a clue to the theme of the questions.  Answer a question on the card correctly and you can move forward and be asked the next question on the card.  You keep going until all questions on the card have been asked, but if you get a wrong answer you could move backward.  The first player around the board wins.

Name: Bostons vs Chicagos Parlor Baseball Game
Description: Bostons vs Chicagos Parlor Baseball Game features a wooden boxed game with a colored lithograph playing field and was published in 1888.

Name: Centre Rock
Description:
A game of territory, defense, and pushing the other guy around! Your foot soldiers will stop at nothing to gain control of The Rock for you, but you must manage shifting alliances, plan ahead while striking now, and catch good fortune to be victorious...

Centre Rock is an abstract strategy game in which 2--4 players vie for control of The Rock. Each player commands a squad consisting of a striker (pikeman), two archers, and two melee units. Movement is based on hexes, and each unit type may attack a particular pattern of surrounding cells. Games take 45--90 minutes.

Centre Rock is also a freely downloadable DIY game.  Full rules, game board, and pieces are available for download on the RocketShip Games website along with detailed instructions for constructing your own copy.

Name: Babe Ruth's Baseball Game
Description: Babe Ruth's Baseball Game was published in 1936. Ruth himself endorsed the game and features a color illustration of Ruth batting with a black and white inset photo of the "Babe". The game has a playing field, deck of playing cards which controls the action in the game, wooden pieces for men and score sheets.

Name: The Dana Girls Game
Description:
The Dana Girls were a series of mystery books similar to Nancy Drew and the Hardy Boys.

The object of this simple roll-and-move game is to be the first player to reach the finish with a set of four Clue cards.  The game comes with 32 Seaman cards, 32 Ruby cards, 4 playing pieces, a die, and a game board.  Clue Cards 1 and 2 are located among the Seaman cards while Clue Cards 3 and 4 are with the Ruby cards.  The board's Police Station is the game's "lucky space."

Name: Warmaster Annual 2003
Description:
Released in 2003, this expansion of Warmaster includes rules for Dark Elf, Skaven, Mercenary (Dogs of War), and Vampire Armies. Also included are the four best articles from the previous year's Warmaster magazine.

Expands:

     Warmaster


From back of the book:

NEW RULES

The new official army lists: Vampire Counts and Dark Elves

TRIAL RULES

The new Skaven Army.

BEST OF WARMAG

The best articles from the last year of Warmaster Magazine including Battles of Legend, The Night Before the Battle, Advice for Green Bosses and Empire Redoubt.

BACK CATALOGUE

The full back catalogue of Warmaster miniatures.

Name: Carl Hubbell's "Strike Three" Baseball
Description:
Carl Hubbell's "Strike Three" Baseball published by Tone Products  in 1946.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by the Yahoo Baseball Games Group. A more complete description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

Name: Red Barber's Big League Baseball Game
Description: G & R Anthony produced Red Barber's Big League Baseball Game in 1950. All the thrills and excitement of real baseball, The box claimed that the game was based on 2000 major league scoring records.

Name: Stork's Nest
Description:
This game claims to be a 19th century Bohemian game replicating the problem people have with storks constructing their huge nests on top of chimneys.

The game consists of a 3-piece wooden house (house, roof, and chimney), and 60 sticks.

The sticks are divided evenly between the players, who take turns placing them in a stack on the chimney.

If a player knocks any sticks off of the nest, they must take all of the fallen sticks and add them to their supply.

The first player to run out of sticks is the winner.

Comes with instructions in English, French, and German.

Name: Caporetto, 1917: Catastrophe for Italy
Description:
Caporetto, 1917
Catastrophe for Italy

By the standards of the Great War, Caporetto was a remarkable battle.  Within a month, the Austro-Germans inflicted over 300,000 Italian casualties at a loss to themselves of only 100,000, and had shifted the front over 100 miles.  But they fell short of a decisive victory.

Caporetto recreates this spectacular offensive.  Modifications to the Great War in the East Standard Rules account for infiltration, naval fire support, changes of command, heroic "last ditch" leadership, and much more.  The game poses different problems for each Player, with the Austro-German player impelled to push his advance as fast and as far as possible and the Italian Player forced to retreat, often in the face of certain losses to his rear-guard units, in order to rebuild his shattered line.  But despite the inherent imbalance of forces, the game is tensely balanced.

Included in the The Great War in the East: Four World War 1 Battles Quadrigame.
Folio edition contains Standard rules, Special rules, 17" x 21" map and 200 counters.
Families: Series: Great War in the East (SPI)

Name: The Brusilov Offensive: Imperial Russia's Last Campaign, 1916
Description:
The Brusilov Offensive
Imperial Russia's Last Campaign, 1916

In mid-May 1916, the Allies were faced with two crises.  At Verdun the French army was gradually being bled to death, and in Trentino, the Italian army was rapidly nearing its breaking point.  As in August 1914, the Allies sent out a call of au secours to the Russians.

The Russians responded on 4 June with an offensive along the entire line of General Brusilov's Southwest Front.  This operation resulted in the capture of some 150,000 square miles of territory, inflicted losses of over 3/4 million, and force the Central Powers to weaken their offensives.  As great as it was, however, the Brusilov Offensive was not the strategically decisive victory the Russians needed to stave off internal collapse.  In the game the Russian player must break through the Central Powers line and encircle masses of enemy troops, while the Central Powers Player must make careful withdrawals and timely counterattacks.  For both Players, the game is demanding and requires coherent planning and careful execution.
Families: Series: Great War in the East (SPI)

Name: Von Hindenburg in Poland: The Warsaw-Lodz Campaign, 1914
Description:
Von Hindenberg in Poland
The Warsaw-Lodz Campaign, 1914

In the wake of Russian successes in Galicia, Grand Duke Nicholas plotted an invasion to the mineral-rich German province of Silesia.  To forestall this, von Hindenberg transferred four German corps from Prussia to the southwest corner of Poland and launched an offensive toward Warsaw.  By 12 October, they had driven the Russians back to the Vistula, just south of Warsaw, but there, outnumbered and over-extended, they ran out of steam.

Von Hindenberg in Poland simulates the intense back-and-forth struggle that began 16 October, with von Hindenberg's retreat from the Vistula.  Over the course of the ensuing six weeks, both sides surged forward and back, east and west, alternately threatening the other with potentially disastrous encirclements.  Special rules cover the effects of inferior Russian intelligence (hidden movement for the Germans), the combined effects of poor Russian logistical capacities and German scorched-earth policies.

Included in the The Great War in the East: Four World War 1 Battles Quadrigame.
Folio edition contains Standard rules, Special rules, 17" x 21" map and 200 counters.
Families: Series: Great War in the East (SPI)

Name: Serbia/Galicia: Austria-Hungary at War, 1914
Description:
Serbia/Galicia
Austria-Hungary at War, 1914

Prior to the outbreak of the Great War, the Chief-of-Staff of the Hapsburg Army, Count Conrad von Hotzendorff, had declared that the Empire's forces were not strong enough to undertake simultaneous full-scale offensives in both Poland and the Balkans. Nevertheless, in the Autumn of 1914, this is what he attempted.

Serbia/Galicia includes a dual map, which illustrates both major fronts on which the Austro-Hungarians were deployed in 1914. The Austro-Serbian border, from Belgrade to Montenegro, is shown on half the map, while the majority of Galicia, including Lemberg and the crucial Prezmysl-fortress complex, is on the other half.  On the first map area, the Austrian forces must try to make headway against the under-equipped but ferocious Serbs, while on the other, the Russians attempt to make up for the disasters in Prussia by overrunning as much of Galicia as possible.  Special rules cover Serbian supply constraints, Austrian river-monitors, and the transfer of Austrian troops.
Families: Series: Great War in the East (SPI)

Name: Het Verkeer en Ik
Description:
The English title would be: the Traffic and Me.
Card game with 26 cards with traffic signs and 26 cards which display those traffic signs in real life situations and one Joker. 
Two extra cards with rules: one for a memory game, another for  an Old Maid-game. 
Drawings were made by Jean-Pol, a famous Belgian comics illustrator.

Name: Monster Crunch
Description:
Each players have monsters cards with teeth. The cards can be flipped.

When a player successfully make a set, he must say crunch! He gets a point if he is correct, and lose one if wrong.

Name: Wheel of Fortune
Description:
Components:
Plastic Chips on 4 colors (coins).
 4 additional silver coins
An electric turntable (uses one battery)

How to play:
Similar game to some gambling arcade machines.
Players get chips of the same color.
Some chips are initially set up on the turntable. The silver coins are also set up on the table.
Simultaneously, players roll their tokens trying to make as many tokens as possible on their baskets.

Scoring is one point per token other than your color and 4 points per silver token.

Name: Character Clues
Description:
This easy-to-play game is a unique way to bring the whole family together for a fun time of fellowship, learning the operational definitions of character qualities, and encouraging the development of these vital qualities in each others’ lives.

The set includes instructions, two types of cards, and a resource booklet in a sturdy case.

Name: Lifestyles of the Poor and Disgusting
Description: This is a roll and move game with no strategy.  Basically, roll and hope to get one of the four things required to win (Food/Shelter/Clothing/Transportation).  Oh yeah, theres are also spaces where players must "Take a Drink".

Name: Mayday
Description:
Mayday is a variant of Werewolf set in the holiday of Mayday.  Players are assigned characters of various iconic figures from the socialist revolutions.  However, there are three traitors, the forces of Greed, Power and Corruption, trying to bring down the revolution from within.  Players must root out the traitors and exile them to Siberia while avoiding that selfsame fate.

Mayday is a print and play game that can be downloaded at http://interactivitiesink.com/larps/mayday/.

Name: ZAGA: Oyunların Efendisi
Description: This game is designed after a very famous TV show "Zaga", which was presented by Okan Bayulgen in Turkish televisions. In this game players roll a dice and move along the sections of the board. In the trivia section, they have to answer questions about the 80's. In the "persons" section, players have to mimic the persons, described in the card. In the "bet" section, players have to bet on the subject, written on the card for one of the players. In the Zaga-live section, one of the players become a guest for the Zaga show. A very exiting and wonderful game. It has lots of jokes and humor for the taste of Turkish people.

Name: Bjørnedans og apestreker
Description:
Bjørnedans og apestreker (Bear dance and monkey business) is a children's dexterity game. The game includes 55 cards with different actions, and rules for four different games:


     "Se hva løver kan!" (Look what lions can do!)
     "Musa kan turne" (The mouse does gymnastics)
     "Dyrenes sirkus" (Animal circus)
     "Konkurranseturning" (Gymnastics competition)


All games are variants of players drawing a card and acting out the action described.

Name: Bikuben
Description: In Bikuben (The bee hive), players control a bee that starts in the center of a hexagonal hive and moves outwards by throwing two dice with six colors. The moves must correspond to the colors on the dice. When arriving the fields outside the hive, the bee collects pollen and starts over again.

Name: Betty Spaghetty
Description:
The game has 60 cards consisting of the head, the body and two feet of "Betty Spaghetty and her friends".

Players take turns to combine the cards in funny ways (but the feet must match!). The person to complete one figure keeps it.

The person with the most figures when the cards run out is the winner.

Name: Spillet om Askepott
Description:
Spillet om Askepott (The Cinderella Game) is a children's game where the players compete to become Cinderella. They have the following tasks to fulfill:


     Find the Fairy Godmother to transform to a princess
     Move to the ball
     Find the watch to transform back
     Try the lost shoe
     Move to the castle again and marry the prince

Name: ALF'a beta
Description:
ALF'a beta is a versatile card game consisting of four decks of all letters of the alphabet (including the Norwegian letters Æ, Ø, Å, and the German letters Ä, Ö and Ü), and one joker (the "ALF") in each deck.

The rules describe many variants on how to play, including learning children how to spell, enriching the vocabulary of older players, making crosswords to challenge the other players, a regular game, "The Pyramid", and two solitaire versions.

Name: Gøy med klokken
Description:
Gøy med klokken (Fun with the clock) is an educational children's game where the players learn to tell the time.

The game has 24 tiles with times of the day, and the players must correctly adjust the hands of the clock on the board according to these tiles.

Name: Mummi: Hattespillet
Description: Based on the "Moomin" characters of the Finnish writer Tove Jansson, the players of this game searches in the garden of the Moomins to find the lost hats of Moominpappa.

Name: Newtonspillet
Description:
Newtonspillet is a spin-off from "Newton", a science program from the official Norwegian Broadcasting (NRK) aimed for youth.

Players move around the board and answers science questions from the following four categories: "Sea and Water", "Land", "Air and Sky" and "The Universe".

Name: Ordjakten
Description: Each turn, the players get a topic and must take turns to name an object of that class (flowers, countries, Norwegian animals etc).

Name: Pelle Politibil: Trafikkspillet
Description:
Pelle Politibil: Trafikkspillet is a Norwegian children's game where each player controls "Pelle politibil" (a police car from a children's television show).

When playing this game, children learn traffic signs and rules.
